thread.title: US Markets Have Been Outperforming the Eurozone - Yahoo Finance
thread.title_full: US Markets Have Been Outperforming the Eurozone - Yahoo Finance

author: Rebecca Keats
title: US Markets Have Been Outperforming the Eurozone - Yahoo Finance
text:
Key for Investors: US Banks Dominate Their European Rivals 
US stocks outperformed the Eurozone The US economy was the primary cause of the recession. As a result, it was hit the most. From September 2008 to March 2009, the US stock markets fell nearly 50%. The stock markets are represented by the S&P 500 SPDR ETF (SPY).
In comparison, Europe did better. The SPDR Euro Stoxx 50 ETF (FEZ) fell 40% during the same period.
Since then, the US markets have recovered better than the Eurozone. SPY rose 169.5% while FEZ rose 43.9%.
Most of the European stock markets’ underperformance is attributed to weaker regulations—compared to the US—and the sovereign debt crisis that struck in 2011. Stocks that partly fueled the rally in US stocks are banks like JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Wells Fargo (WFC), Bank of America (BAC), and Citigroup (C).
Understanding macroeconomic differences On a macro level, the European stock markets have all of the characteristics that investors look for. The ECB’s (European Central Bank) QE (quantitative easing) program is boosting the Eurozone. The US is contemplating raising interest rates after the QE program ends.
The MSCI European Index has a PE (price-to-earnings) ratio of 16.90x versus 20.52x for the S&P 500 Index. Europe’s stock markets may appear cheaper if you look at these valuations. However, it’s important to consider economic fundamentals.
Continue to Next Part
